Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research in Biophotonics: Implantable sensor for brain blood flow mapping

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1264927/1264948
Kymissis/Ma

This program will develop a new platform for biophotonics using thin film organic semiconductor materials capable of generating and detecting light in a thin, flexible form factor. The proposed architecture overcomes both the limitations of previously demonstrated implantable systems, as well as the challenges (environmental stability and device cross-coupling) traditionally associated with thin film systems. They will build a series of blood flow monitors using flexible organic light emitting diodes (OLEDs) and organic photodetectors (OPDs) to map both oxygenation and total hemoglobin in the brain, increasing in size, scale, and complexity as the program progresses. They will demonstrate the functionality and stability of the systems using both simulated condition testing and implanted devices. This platform applies OLED technology, which has had a significant impact in displays, to build a transformative light source for biological research that is capable of implantation in nearly any configuration and can be used to image reflectance and fluorescence over large areas for extended periods of time. This thin, flexible platform can bring this new perspective and capability to a broad class of imaging, optogenetic, fluorescence measurement, and other biophotonic applications.

This award is co-funded by the IDBR program (Instrument Development for Biological Research) in the BIO Directorate, and Biophotonics program in the Engineering Directorate.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This program is intended to develop a new platform for biophotonics using thin film organic emiconductor materials capable of generating and detecting light in a thin, flexible form factor that can be implanted invivo. The program goal is to build, as a demonstration module, an 8x8 implantable subcranial blood flow monitor using flexible organic light emitting diodes (OLEDs) and organic photodetectors (OPDs) to map both oxygenation and total hemoglobin in the brain. This system addresses many of the complications associated with using thin film optoelectronics in biophotonic applications, and can also be applied to a range of other invivo and invitro applications.

During the three year program period, we have accomplished the following academic goals:

  1. We have completed several generations of system construction, and finalized a single pixel device, a dual pixel/dual color version of the device, and a 4x4 array light emitter on a 2 micron thick substrate co-integrated with a thin film photodetector.  The thin film is a biocompatible, flexible and transparent, which is suitable for intracranial implantation. This substrate provides intimate contact with the brain tissule. The phosphorescent OLEDs provide higher brightness. These features allow for higher resolution of blood flow and activity monitoring than otherwise possible, and also suppresses waveguiding between the emitting and detecting elements while maintaining a reasonable barrier against water in the environment. Development of a new power supply and synchronous detector system at the implant level
  2. We have demonstrated this system on a rat model in each format and has demonstrated an SNR comparable with single pixel inorganic LEDs and superior to suspended cameras (which represent the state of the art) for the same application
  3. The lifetime of the thin film devices has been well managed, and the system now operates for the duration of acute experiments immersed under water, meeting the program goals
  4. A dual color light source tuned for optogenetic manipulation has been demonstrated, suitable test animals are now being prepared for testing
  5. Safety testing of the system was recently completed on a mouse model, demonstrating suitability for long-term implantation
  6. Study of the seizure activity and blood flow in the rat model provide insights to interpret the imaging results.

Besides these academic achievements, the program has also provided opportunities for training of several graduate students in the cross-disciplinary areas of optical device design and fabrication, benchtop testing, and animal testing.  Students have also been able to participate in presenting the results, both in presentations and at demonstration sessions at local and international conferences and workshops on optical and display engineering. 

We have published our results in academic journals and conferences to disseminate to communities of interest:

  • Ma H, Harris S, Rahmani R, Lacefield CO, Zhao M, Daniel AG, Zhou Z, Bruno RM, Berwick J,Schwartz TH (2014). Wide-field in vivo neocortical calcium dye imaging using a convection-enhanced loading technique combined with simultaneous multiwavelength imaging of voltage-sensitive dyes and hemodynamic.  Neurophotonics. 1 (1); DOI: 10.1117/1.NPh.1.1.015003
  • Youngwan Kim, Christopher Choi ; En-Chen Chen ; Andy G. S. Daniel ; Amrita Masurkar ; Theodore H. Conference Presentations:

  • Youngwan Kim, Christopher Choi, Amrita Masurkar, Hongtao Ma, Theodore Schwartz, Ioannis Kymissis (2014). An Implantable System for Brain Blood Flow Monitoring Using Flexible OLEDs and OPDs. FlexTech 2014. Phoenix, AZ.
  • Youngwan Kim, Amrita Masurkar, Hongtao Ma, Theodore Schwartz, Ioannis Kymissis (2014). An implantable system for brain blood flow monitoring. SPIE Organic Semiconductors in Biolelectronics. San Diego, CA.

  • Hongtao Ma, Andy Daniel, Philippe, Laffront, Mingrui Zhao, Theodore Schwartz (2015). Glial Waves During Seizures - Coupled or Uncoupled with Vascular Activity?. American Epilepsy Society. Philadelphia, PA.
